course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Information Systems Auditing
course.description: The course provides a comprehensive approach for auditing information systems. It covers fundamental concepts of risk management for Information Systems (IS) auditors to perform risk assessment, and risk analysis at various business levels, including systems, administrative and organizational levels. The course also covers business cases for students to study, and provides opportunities for them to apply their IS auditing skills to solve those cases from IS auditing perspectives. Typical solutions to those cases are effective, reasonable, and practical controls. Other IS auditing practices, such as compliance audit and governance audit, and auditing system development life cycle are covered as well, in order to provide a holistic training of IS auditing to students.
course.prerequisites: ACCT 2010 and ISOM 2010

reviews.author: 棉花糖
reviews.title: Group project determines your grade
reviews.comment_content:
It can be either IS elective/IS auditing option required course. So it covers SOME content of the CISA (Certified Information Systems Auditor) exam. You can refer to other reviews for the topics covered.

Easy and not a lot of concepts (compared with other IS courses) HOWEVER I suggest everyone should either attend lessons/watch lecture recordings if you want to get a good grade as his PPT are not suffice to do well.

The in-class quizzes and final exam often asks about what he emphasizes in class multiple times. So try to catch what is important by attending classes.
reviews.comment_teaching:
James is a Hong Kong professor, so his accent is okay. His teaching style is more freestyle than like a lecturer. What I mean is he could spend a lot of time on explaining a concept and wanders off to talking about points NOT in the PPT (that's why you need to jot notes as you listen/rewatch lecture recordings) or else you will lose A LOT of scores in all assessments.

I would say his teaching is both easy and hard to follow. Easy in a sense you can easily understand what he is saying, however, you need to focus and pay attention to have a better sense of what the MAIN POINT is, which will likely appear in in-class exercises and final.

Tip: If you hear repeated keywords, it is likely important. Also, he will ask about a certain keyword e.g. CVE so just copy as much notes as possible and print them out for the final exam
reviews.comment_grading:
Please look at the score breakdown and what I attained and determine if you want to risk your grade lol

Breakdown:
1. Assignment (Group) 30%
2. 3 In-class exercise (Individual and closed-book) 30%
Note: 4 in total. Counts the best 3. Difficulty is similar for all.
3. Final Exam (Open-book) 40%

My scores:
1. almost lowest (not exposing myself lol) Mean 24.3 High 28.5 Low 21
2. 29.8/30 Mean ranges from 7-8 (above average for all 4)
3. 32.63/40 (lower than mean) Mean 33.25 High 38.63 Low 21.88

Overall:
Just as what I put in the title. Your grade is pretty much determined by your group project. However, your group mates are assigned to you. His grading is NOT transparent at all. No free riders in my group. However, it is hard to understand what James want. We asked for feedback since we are almost lowest, and the comments are pointless. We have no idea how we lost that many scores. I am a bit disappointed by the group project scores. Ranting aside, a piece of advice would be to read other reviews on how to nail the group project. All in all, I think you have to follow what James emphasized in class and try your best.

In my opinion, doing well (is not hard, given that your lowest score is dropped) in in-class exercises is not enough, or I should say doesn't matter as much as doing well in finals and the group project. The group project is released in mid Nov (and yes, during project peaks) and you have 2 weeks to pull off a 10-minute video presentation with a PPT supplemented by a report. Everyone has to present their own parts so I think it is unlikely to have a free rider but do start early once the assignment is released so you have more time to fine tune your content and all. From what I heard, if you are able to attain the highest score for the project, you can get A range. So, really work hard on the project.

As for the final exam, James is nice enough to make it open-book. As you can imagine, when it is open-book, everyone does well lol. The time is not tight at all. So I think jotting notes onto your notes is useful. I printed out all lecture slides. Some questions could be tricky, so nobody is able to score full marks. Not sure how to achieve higher as I think he may change the questions next year. But one question I lost marks in needs you to explain in your own words instead of copying from his lecture slides which he explains in his own words. So, this is a trap I fell into I guess. But who would have guessed he wants us to use our own words to explain. I mean, good luck ;)

Final Grade: B

Worst grade of all my courses this semester with seemingly easiest course content. My last word is to mentally prepare those who are patient enough to read till here: don't be fooled by the easy course content. Still hard to get A range. Needs much more effort if you want A range. I should have worked harder for the group project and final exam :(
reviews.comment_workload:
The 'Grading' part pretty much explains the extent of effort this course requires. Just as any ISOM/UST course, exert all your effort (despite the easy content) if you want A range. Otherwise, I think with minimal effort e.g. attending classes and jotting notes, very easy to get B range, if this is all you want.

Think through how to do well in the project and DO NOT take it lightly.

If you want B range, reg this; if you want A range, work harder.

reviews.author: hlll
reviews.title: Don't take this course unless you want to fulfill the IS auditing option
reviews.comment_content:
An introduction to IS auditing, teaching fairly simple concepts only. The whole course circulates around the topic of "Risks" and "Controls". No quantitative or very technical content is covered. It's a bit disappointing that some knowledge learnt are like "your mum is woman", so I don't feel I have learnt a lot after taking this course.

Some content of this course overlaps with ISOM4300, so it is ok to take both ISOM4100 and ISOM4300 in the same semester. You wouldn't want to keep learning Risks and Controls in two separate semesters.
reviews.comment_teaching:
James Kwok's explanation on concepts can vary every week. He give you a certain definition on the first week, and then after a few weeks he can overturn what he had said before. So you'll have no idea which definition to follow in exam.

His lectures are quite boring in my opinion. He can spend 30mins reviewing what is taught in the previous class, and then spend another 30mins explaining a single slide. You'll have to jot a lot of notes because his slides cover only a very limited portion of what he taught in class.

He isn't very helpful when we ask him something about the group assignment either. Most of the time he just said "It's ok as long as it makes sense". Not much constructive feedback on our work, so I still have no idea why we scored so poorly for the group assignment.

The good thing about him is that he teaches quite slowly, and will post the lecture recordings on Canvas, so you should be able to follow and can rewatch the lectures if you find it helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment (x1) (Group, with video presentation) - 30%
In-class exercise (best 3 out of 4) (Individual) - 30%
Final Exam - 40%

Since the content is not difficult, the SD of all these assessments are very low. I scored well in the in class exercises, below median for assignment, and at median for final exam. Final grading is B. I don't think B is a very nice grade, given that B is the wost grade I've ever had. Besides, I scored A+ in ISOM4300, so I don't think I do not understand IS auditing very well.
reviews.comment_workload:
As I said, the in class exercises are very easy so you don't need to spend much time revising for it. The group assignment is fairly simple, won't take much time to complete too.

(Yet, having a simple group assignment does not mean you will get a good grade easily. James got quite a "special taste". For our pre-recorded video presentation, he complimented a group who put background music to their Zoom recorded presentation. He said he appreciate that group adding music, and literally everyone in class were giggling when we heard this comment.)

reviews.author: imcat
reviews.title: Confusion & Misalignment
reviews.comment_content:
I can't say whether ISOM4100 or ISOM4300 is the introduction to IS Auditing course - but this seems more like it. The course teaches me the importance of "un-learning" everything that you have experience in.

1 Core Reminder: Justify everything you've identified with documentations from the company/case subject. DO NOT justify your risk by inferencing stuff from the case - e.g., by justifying that a risk is possible with external literature or stuff. Just read the case and outline & explain the obvious is enough.

Risk = Likelihood x Consequence/Negative Impacts.

As for Final Exam & Project Assignment - just remember everything needs to be related to Business Objectives, B-case, and whatever about Expected Benefits those kind of stuff. It is not something understanding "concepts" or rote memorisation can help - you need to somehow be mentally linked with James to understand what he wants.

This is another talk-heavy course with no technical stuff discussed. If you know nothing about cybersecurity, risks, and controls, you may find this course interesting and easy-to-handle. For me, what the course teaches just confuses me with what I know in real life.

By the way, even after the course, I still cannot distinguish between Personal Data, Confidential Data, and Sensitive Data - maybe it is just me being incompetent.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Pros: James always tries to explain everything.

Cons:
1. James' lecture slides are a bit chaotic - you must attend his lectures/watch the lecture recordings to understand what are them (the slides' layout seem to be from PPT's Design Ideas). It can be his intention to make you attend his classes - I have no issues with this, just put a little extra effort to organise everything on your own.

2. James' explanations can vary between classes. An explanation given in the previous class can be different in the next - I would say this gave rise to my confusion about the 3 types of Data.

3. Risks - James mentioned several Major Risks throughout his lectures: Compliance and Data (C/I/A). His way of explaining all these risks just gave me an impression of framing everything under these Major Risks - so they are sort of a category of the Negative Impacts that we can identify from cases. However, from what I understand from his feedback on the Project Assignment, the DPPs in the Compliance Risk (PDPO) can be discussed separately. I was utterly confused but it is what he expects. As a student, I can only blame myself for not asking sufficient questions during the assignment and not asking him tons of questions to understand what "Risk" actually is.

4. Controls - the controls taught are literally just what you can find on Google. The course teaches you how to frame your control to be "Effective", "Reasonable", and "Practical" with "sufficient evidence".
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Components:
1. In-class Exercise (30%):
- 4 in total
- Best 3 counted towards final grade

2. Project Assignment (30%):
- You have 2 weeks to complete the Project
- A case is given with several articles for your understanding
- Need to submit a Presentation Slide, Written Report, and a Presentation Recording

3. Final Exam (40%):
- All Short Questions with word limit
- Open-book
- Test you on stuff he talked during lectures - virtually nothing from his slides, SO TAKE NOTES during classes

Me:
1. ~ 29/30
2. ~ 37/40
3. ~ 22/30
Final Grade: B

Distribution should be very skewed given means are high. Screwing up the Project Assignment = you should no expectation about the final grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light.

1. MEMORISE everything James went through in the lectures before the in-class exercise.

2. Do NOT make the mistakes I mentioned for the Project Assignment - it takes at most 3 days for the group to sit down and get everything done.

3. Consolidate all notes for the final exam, take your notes to the exam venue. Bear in mind the word limit and you should be fine.

Whether or not you will screw up the course depends on your Project's score. I underestimated James' expectation and the complete misalignment got me to hell.
